quiz.title: Unit 9: Unemployment and Inflation (Quiz 9)
quiz.subtitle: 9.9 The Phillips Curve: Inflation-Unemployment Tradeoff (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics

questions.question: The original Phillips Curve showed an inverse relationship between:
options: Inflation and interest rates
Inflation and unemployment
Money supply and prices
Government spending and taxes
questions.explanation: A.W. Phillips' original 1958 study found an inverse relationship between wage inflation and unemployment in the UK - lower unemployment was associated with higher wage growth.

questions.question: The short-run Phillips Curve suggests that policymakers can:
options: Permanently reduce unemployment by accepting higher inflation
Achieve both low inflation and low unemployment simultaneously
Trade off higher inflation for lower unemployment temporarily
Ignore the relationship between inflation and unemployment
questions.explanation: The short-run Phillips Curve suggests a temporary trade-off where expansionary policies can reduce unemployment by accepting higher inflation, but only until expectations adjust.

questions.question: The natural rate hypothesis states that in the long run:
options: The Phillips Curve is downward sloping
There is a permanent trade-off between inflation and unemployment
The Phillips Curve is vertical at the natural rate of unemployment
Unemployment can be zero with sufficient inflation
questions.explanation: The natural rate hypothesis, developed by Milton Friedman and Edmund Phelps, states that the long-run Phillips Curve is vertical at the natural rate of unemployment - there's no permanent inflation-unemployment trade-off.

questions.question: The expectations-augmented Phillips Curve includes:
options: Only actual inflation
Actual inflation and expected inflation
Only unemployment rates
Government policy variables only
questions.explanation: The expectations-augmented Phillips Curve shows that inflation depends on both expected inflation and the deviation of unemployment from its natural rate: π = πᵉ - β(u - uⁿ).

questions.question: Adaptive expectations in the Phillips Curve model mean that people:
options: Perfectly predict future inflation
Base expectations solely on recent inflation experience
Never change their inflation expectations
Use complex economic models to forecast inflation
questions.explanation: With adaptive expectations, people form expectations based on recent past inflation, gradually adjusting their expectations as new data becomes available.

questions.question: The sacrifice ratio measures:
options: The percentage point increase in inflation needed to reduce unemployment by 1%
The percentage point increase in unemployment needed to reduce inflation by 1%
The trade-off between government spending and taxes
The cost of unemployment benefits as a percentage of GDP
questions.explanation: The sacrifice ratio measures the cumulative percentage point-years of excess unemployment needed to reduce inflation by 1 percentage point.

questions.question: During the 1970s stagflation period, the Phillips Curve relationship:
options: Became stronger and more predictable
Broke down as both inflation and unemployment rose
Proved the permanent trade-off theory correct
Showed that unemployment could be zero
questions.explanation: The 1970s stagflation (high inflation and high unemployment simultaneously) contradicted the original Phillips Curve and supported the natural rate hypothesis.

questions.question: Rational expectations theory suggests that:
options: People make systematic forecasting errors
People use all available information efficiently
Expectations adjust very slowly to new information
Only economists can form accurate expectations
questions.explanation: Rational expectations theory assumes people use all available information efficiently and don't make systematic errors in forecasting, making anticipated policy changes ineffective.

questions.question: The non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment (NAIRU) is:
options: The unemployment rate when inflation is zero
The unemployment rate consistent with stable inflation
The minimum possible unemployment rate
The average unemployment rate over a business cycle
questions.explanation: NAIRU is the unemployment rate at which inflation does not accelerate - it's essentially equivalent to the natural rate of unemployment.

questions.question: If the public has rational expectations and policy is anticipated, attempts to reduce unemployment below the natural rate will:
options: Succeed permanently
Cause immediate inflation without reducing unemployment
Have no effect on inflation
Reduce both inflation and unemployment
questions.explanation: With rational expectations and anticipated policy, workers and firms immediately adjust prices and wages, causing inflation to rise without any temporary reduction in unemployment.

questions.question: The long-run Phillips Curve is vertical because:
options: Inflation always equals expected inflation in the long run
Unemployment is always constant in the long run
The natural rate of unemployment changes with inflation
Government policy can permanently control unemployment
questions.explanation: In the long run, actual inflation equals expected inflation (π = πᵉ), so the Phillips Curve equation becomes u = uⁿ regardless of the inflation rate.

questions.question: Which policy would cause movement along the short-run Phillips Curve?
options: A permanent increase in the natural rate of unemployment
An unexpected expansionary monetary policy
A change in inflation expectations
Structural reforms to labor markets
questions.explanation: Unexpected expansionary policy causes movement along the short-run Phillips Curve, temporarily reducing unemployment while increasing inflation.

questions.question: A supply shock (like an oil price increase) would cause:
options: Movement along the Phillips Curve
A shift of the Phillips Curve
No change in the Phillips Curve relationship
The Phillips Curve to become horizontal
questions.explanation: Supply shocks shift the Phillips Curve outward, worsening the trade-off by increasing both inflation and unemployment at any given point.

questions.question: The credibility of central bank policy affects the Phillips Curve because:
options: It doesn't influence inflation expectations
Credible anti-inflation policy reduces the sacrifice ratio
Only actual policy actions matter, not credibility
Credibility makes the long-run curve horizontal
questions.explanation: When a central bank has high credibility, inflation expectations adjust quickly, reducing the unemployment cost (sacrifice ratio) of disinflation policies.

questions.question: The 'accelerationist hypothesis' suggests that:
options: Inflation accelerates automatically over time
Keeping unemployment below the natural rate requires accelerating inflation
Unemployment accelerates when inflation is high
Economic growth accelerates with moderate inflation
questions.explanation: The accelerationist hypothesis states that maintaining unemployment below the natural rate requires continually increasing inflation (accelerating inflation) to stay ahead of rising expectations.

questions.question: Which factor could cause the long-run Phillips Curve to shift?
options: Temporary demand shocks
Changes in the natural rate of unemployment
Short-term monetary policy changes
Cyclical fluctuations in unemployment
questions.explanation: The long-run Phillips Curve shifts when the natural rate of unemployment changes due to demographic shifts, labor market institutions, or structural factors.

questions.question: In the new Keynesian Phillips Curve, inflation depends on:
options: Only past inflation
Expected future inflation and real marginal costs
Only current unemployment rates
Government budget deficits
questions.explanation: The new Keynesian Phillips Curve derives from microfoundations and shows inflation depends on expected future inflation and the output gap (related to real marginal costs).

questions.question: The 'Lucas critique' argues that:
options: Phillips Curve relationships are stable over time
Economic relationships change when policies change
Inflation and unemployment are unrelated
Only adaptive expectations matter for policy
questions.explanation: The Lucas critique states that estimated economic relationships (like the Phillips Curve) may change when policy regimes change because people adjust their behavior based on expectations of policy.

questions.question: During disinflation, the short-run Phillips Curve:
options: Shifts inward immediately
Shifts outward temporarily
Becomes horizontal
Doesn't change position
questions.explanation: During disinflation, the short-run Phillips Curve shifts outward temporarily as the economy experiences higher unemployment while inflation expectations adjust downward.

questions.question: The modern view of the Phillips Curve emphasizes that:
options: There is a permanent inflation-unemployment trade-off
The trade-off exists only in the short run with sticky prices
Inflation and unemployment are completely independent
Only supply factors determine both inflation and unemployment
questions.explanation: Modern macroeconomics, incorporating price stickiness and expectations, recognizes a short-run trade-off due to nominal rigidities, but no long-run trade-off.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand the Phillips Curve, its evolution, and the role of expectations in the inflation-unemployment relationship.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basic concepts but should review the differences between short-run and long-run Phillips Curves and how expectations affect the relationship.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: the original Phillips Curve finding, the natural rate hypothesis, and why the trade-off exists only in the short run.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that the Phillips Curve shows an inflation-unemployment trade-off that exists only in the short run, and the long-run curve is vertical at the natural rate of unemployment.
